writing_prompt: A master art forger turned FBI consultant finds himself at a crossroads when his old partner proposes a heist that feels... wrong. For the first time, he hesitates—has he really changed, or is he just fooling himself?
story:
Neal Caffrey stood in his loft, the city lights of New York casting long shadows across the room. The artifacts of his past life - the sketches, the easels, the half-finished masterpieces - stood as silent witnesses to his internal turmoil. The offer had come unexpectedly, a whisper from the shadows of a life he thought he had left behind. An old partner, a friend from his days of forgery and deception, had resurfaced with a proposal that had shaken him to his core.

Vincent.

The name alone brought a flood of memories. They had been inseparable once, bound by their shared talent and hunger for the art world’s treasures. But now, Vincent's proposition felt like a ghostly echo, a siren's call to a life Neal had tried so hard to escape.

Neal paced, his mind a battlefield of conflicting desires. He had spent years building a new life, working alongside the FBI, proving to himself and to Peter Burke that he could be more than just a con artist. Yet here he was, standing on the precipice of a decision that could unravel everything.

The heist Vincent proposed was unlike any they had ever planned. It wasn’t just about the money or the thrill. It was about a piece of art so rare, so intrinsically valuable, that it transcended mere monetary worth. But there was something else, something darker that Neal couldn’t quite put his finger on. The way Vincent had spoken, the urgency in his voice, the subtle hints of desperation - it all felt wrong.

Neal's thoughts drifted to Peter, the man who had given him a second chance. Peter had seen something in him, something worth saving. The trust they had built wasn’t just professional; it was personal, a bond forged through trials and triumphs. Could he betray that trust for the lure of the past?

He picked up a sketchpad, absentmindedly drawing, letting his thoughts flow with the pencil's movements. The face that emerged on the paper was familiar, hauntingly so. Kate. She had been his muse, his lover, his partner in crime. Her loss had shattered him, pushing him further into the world of cons and heists. But even she, with her love for the thrill, would have hesitated at Vincent's proposal.

Neal sighed, dropping the sketchpad. He walked over to the window, looking out at the city that had become his home, his sanctuary. The temptation was strong, the pull of the past almost irresistible. But he wasn’t the same man he had been. He had changed, or at least he wanted to believe he had.

A knock on the door broke his reverie. He turned, half expecting to see Peter, but it was Mozzie. The little guy had a way of showing up when Neal needed him most.

“Neal, you look like you’ve seen a ghost,” Mozzie said, his eyes scanning the room, taking in the scattered sketches and the look of torment on Neal’s face.

“Vincent’s back,” Neal replied, his voice barely above a whisper.

Mozzie’s eyes widened. “Vincent? As in Vincent Vincent?”

Neal nodded. “He has a proposition. A heist. But something about it feels wrong.”

Mozzie frowned, his usual flippant demeanor replaced by genuine concern. “Neal, you’ve come a long way. You’re not that guy anymore. You’ve got a good thing going with the FBI, with Peter. Don’t throw it away for a ghost from the past.”

Neal stared at Mozzie, the words resonating deep within him. He had changed. He had to believe that.

“I know, Moz. It’s just… it’s hard to let go.”

Mozzie stepped closer, placing a hand on Neal’s shoulder. “Sometimes, letting go is the only way to move forward.”

Neal nodded, feeling a weight lift from his shoulders. He knew what he had to do. He couldn’t go back. He wouldn’t.

The next morning, Neal walked into the FBI office, his resolve firm. Peter looked up from his desk, a question in his eyes.

“Peter, there’s something you need to know,” Neal began, his voice steady. “Vincent’s back, and he proposed a heist. But I’m not going to do it. I’ve changed. I want to prove that.”

Peter’s expression softened, a mixture of pride and relief. “I know you have, Neal. And I’m proud of you.”

The decision had been made, but the journey was far from over. Neal Caffrey had taken a step forward, leaving the shadows of his past behind. The road ahead was uncertain, but for the first time, he felt a glimmer of hope that he was on the right path.

writing_prompt: When Crowley ran into Dean Winchester after years apart, he never expected it to lead to late-night confessions, stolen kisses, and a life tangled with federal agents and family barbecues. But some things, it seems, are worth rewriting the plan for.
story:
Crowley never expected to see Dean Winchester again, especially not in the middle of a crowded New York street. The demon had been minding his own business, conducting a rather mundane deal with a local warlock, when he spotted the familiar swagger and leather jacket pushing through the throng of people. Dean, looking just as ruggedly handsome as ever, seemed oblivious to Crowley’s presence until their eyes met.

“Crowley?” Dean’s voice was a mix of surprise and suspicion.

“Well, well, if it isn’t Squirrel,” Crowley drawled, a smirk playing at the corners of his lips. “Fancy meeting you here.”

Dean’s eyes narrowed, but there was a glint of something else—something softer, hidden beneath the layers of hunter wariness. “What are you doing here?”

“Business, of course,” Crowley replied smoothly. “But now that you’re here, perhaps I’ll extend my stay.”

That night, over a shared bottle of whiskey in a dimly lit bar, the walls between them began to crumble. They talked about the past, about hunts and deals, about the years that had slipped away since their last encounter. As the night grew darker, their confessions grew deeper.

“I never stopped thinking about you, you know,” Dean admitted, his voice barely above a whisper. Crowley’s heart, if he had one, would have skipped a beat.

“Neither did I,” Crowley confessed, leaning in closer. The air between them was charged with an electricity that had been missing from his life for too long.

The first kiss was hesitant, almost shy, but it quickly grew passionate. Stolen kisses in the back alley behind the bar became a routine—an escape from their chaotic lives. But as always, reality had a way of intruding.

Crowley’s empire was never truly safe, and Dean’s life as a hunter was fraught with peril. It wasn’t long before federal agents started sniffing around, their interest piqued by the unusual activities surrounding Crowley’s business. Dean’s involvement only added fuel to the fire.

“Agent Hendrickson,” Dean muttered, glancing over his shoulder at the nondescript black car parked outside the diner where they were having breakfast. “He’s persistent.”

“Persistent, yes, but not particularly bright,” Crowley replied, nonchalantly sipping his coffee. “We’ve dealt with worse.”

Dean’s lips twitched into a half-smile. “Yeah, I suppose we have.”

Despite the danger, they found ways to be together. Crowley’s lair became a sanctuary of sorts—a place where they could steal moments of normalcy amidst the chaos. They cooked dinners together, watched bad movies, and even argued about which toppings belonged on a pizza.

But it wasn’t just the two of them. Dean’s family, the Winchesters, were a package deal. Crowley found himself invited to family barbecues, where he met Sam, who eyed him with a mix of suspicion and grudging acceptance, and even Mary, who surprised him with her warmth.

“You’re good for him,” Mary said one evening, as they stood by the grill, watching Dean and Sam bicker over who made the better burger. “I didn’t think I’d ever see Dean this happy.”

Crowley chuckled. “I suppose we balance each other out.”

Life was never simple, though. There were close calls with the federal agents, and more than once, Crowley had to use his demonic powers to get them out of tight spots. But through it all, their bond only grew stronger.

One particularly harrowing night, after a narrow escape from a federal raid, they found themselves back in Crowley’s lair, bruised but unbroken. Dean was pacing, his frustration palpable.

“This can’t keep happening,” Dean snapped. “We can’t keep living like this.”

Crowley grabbed his arm, pulling him close. “Then let’s change it.”

Dean’s eyes searched his, confusion and hope mingling. “What are you saying?”

“I’m saying,” Crowley began, his voice steady, “that we can rewrite the plan. We don’t have to keep running. We can find a way to be together, without all this chaos.”

Dean looked at him for a long moment before nodding. “Alright. Let’s do it.”

And so they did. It wasn’t easy, but they found a way to balance their lives. Crowley streamlined his empire, cutting ties with the shadier elements and focusing on more legitimate ventures. Dean continued to hunt, but with Crowley’s help, they were always one step ahead of the agents.

In the end, it was worth it. They built a life together, one filled with late-night confessions, stolen kisses, and yes, even family barbecues. It wasn’t the life they had planned, but it was the one they chose—together. And for Crowley, that made all the difference.

writing_prompt: A con artist turned FBI consultant accidentally finds himself defending proper legal procedures during a heated case discussion—much to the amusement of his by-the-book handler, who never lets him live it down.
story:
The room was filled with the usual tension of a high-stakes FBI case meeting. Neal Caffrey lounged in his chair, casually flipping through the case file as if he were reading a novel rather than details of a high-profile art theft. Across from him, Peter Burke sat with a furrowed brow, meticulously going over the evidence with his team.

"Alright, here's what we've got," Peter began, his voice steady and authoritative. "The stolen Monet resurfaced at an auction house in Paris, but we suspect it's a forgery."

Neal raised an eyebrow, a smirk playing at his lips. "A forgery? That's ambitious. Even for me."

Peter shot him a look, half amusement, half exasperation. "Yes, Neal, we know. That's why you're here."

As the discussion continued, the team tossed around theories and strategies. Neal listened with half an ear, more interested in the way Peter's mind worked than the actual details of the case. It was always fascinating to see how differently they approached the same problem.

Then, Diana suggested cutting a few procedural corners to speed up their investigation. "We could bypass the warrant and get the information directly from the auction house," she proposed. "It would save us a lot of time."

Neal's head snapped up. "Hold on a second," he interjected, surprising everyone, including himself. "We can't just ignore proper legal procedures."

The room fell silent. Peter blinked, clearly taken aback. "Did you just—"

Neal held up a hand, his face serious. "If we bypass the warrant, anything we find could be inadmissible in court. We have to do this by the book."

Jones chuckled. "Neal Caffrey, defender of legal procedures. Never thought I'd see the day."

Neal crossed his arms, leaning back in his chair. "Laugh all you want, but what's the point of catching the thief if we can't make the charges stick? Trust me, I know how to exploit legal loopholes better than anyone. We need to make sure we're airtight."

Peter's lips twitched, fighting a smile. "Neal's right. We do this by the book."

The discussion resumed, but now with a new dynamic. Neal found himself unexpectedly at the center of it, his insights taken seriously in a way they hadn't been before. It was a strange feeling, being on the side of the law rather than trying to outsmart it.

After the meeting, Peter cornered Neal in the hallway. "I have to admit, I didn't see that coming."

Neal shrugged, trying to play it off. "Just because I know how to break the rules doesn't mean I don't understand their importance."

Peter chuckled. "Oh, I'm never letting you live this down. Neal Caffrey, the champion of legal procedures. It's too good."

Neal rolled his eyes but couldn't help the smile that tugged at his lips. "Yeah, yeah. Just don't expect it to become a habit."

As the days passed, the case progressed. Neal and Peter worked closely together, their dynamic shifting subtly. There was more mutual respect, a deeper understanding of each other's strengths and weaknesses. Neal found himself enjoying the partnership more than he cared to admit.

One evening, they were in Peter's office, poring over the latest reports. Neal leaned back in his chair, stretching. "You know, this whole 'doing things by the book' isn't so bad."

Peter glanced up, a grin spreading across his face. "Oh? Thinking of going straight, Caffrey?"

Neal laughed. "Let's not get carried away. But it's nice to know that my skills can be used for something good. Even if it means following the rules."

Peter's expression softened. "You know, Neal, I always believed you had it in you. That's why I fought so hard to get you on this team."

Neal looked down, suddenly feeling a warmth in his chest that he wasn't used to. "Thanks, Peter. That means a lot."

They continued to work in comfortable silence, the bond between them stronger than ever. The case was nearing its conclusion, and Neal knew they were close to catching the thief. But more importantly, he realized that he was part of something bigger, something meaningful.

As they finally cracked the case and the thief was brought to justice, Neal couldn't help but feel a sense of pride. Not just in the work they had done, but in the fact that he had played a crucial role in it. And all while following proper legal procedures.

Peter clapped him on the back as they watched the perp being led away in handcuffs. "You did good, Neal."

Neal smiled, a genuine, heartfelt smile. "We did good, Peter."

And for once, Neal Caffrey felt like he was exactly where he belonged.

writing_prompt: The starship is stranded, dead in space, with no apparent reason for the failure. As the clock ticks down and theories crumble, the chief engineer must uncover the truth before the crew's time runs out.
story:
The USS Enterprise shuddered and then went silent, every system aboard going dark. Captain Kirk's voice crackled over the intercom, "Scotty, what just happened?"

In Engineering, Chief Engineer Montgomery Scott was already moving, the emergency lights casting eerie shadows. "Captain, it seems we've lost all power. I'm checking the systems now." He barked orders to his team, their faces pale in the dim red glow.

The initial diagnostics revealed nothing. Scotty’s brow furrowed as he scanned the readouts. The warp core was stable, the dilithium crystals intact, yet the ship was dead in space. His first theory, a power overload, was quickly dismissed. It was as if the ship had been unplugged from the universe.

"Mr. Scott, what’s the status?" Kirk demanded.

"We're working on it, sir. It’s not an easy fix," Scotty replied, frustration creeping into his voice. He could feel the eyes of his crew on him, their confidence resting on his shoulders.

"Keep me updated. Kirk out."

Scotty turned to his assistant, Lieutenant DeSalle. "Check the EPS conduits. If there's a breach, we’ll need to reroute power manually."

DeSalle nodded and hurried off. Scotty moved to the main console, his fingers flying over the controls. The clock was ticking. Life support would hold for a few hours, but with no propulsion or communication, they were sitting ducks.

As he worked, he couldn't shake the feeling that something was off. This wasn’t a typical malfunction. He prided himself on knowing every inch of the Enterprise, and this situation didn’t fit any known pattern.

"Scotty, the EPS conduits are clear," DeSalle reported.

Scotty nodded, but his mind was already racing to the next possibility. "Check the plasma injectors. If they’re clogged, it could cause a cascade failure."

Another dead end. The injectors were clean. The list of potential problems was growing shorter, and the tension in Engineering was palpable. He could hear the murmurs of the crew, their fear barely contained. Scotty took a deep breath, forcing himself to remain calm. He needed to think, to find the missing piece of the puzzle.

"Lieutenant Uhura to Engineering," the intercom crackled. "We’ve lost all external communications. There’s no way to send or receive messages."

"Acknowledged, Lieutenant," Scotty replied. He had expected as much, but hearing it confirmed made the situation feel even more dire.

The next few hours were a blur of activity and frustration. Each theory Scotty proposed fell apart under scrutiny. It was as if the Enterprise was mocking him, its systems taunting him with their inexplicable failure.

"Scotty, we’re running out of time," Kirk's voice was tense.

Scotty knew it too well. He could feel the weight of the crew’s lives pressing down on him. He closed his eyes for a moment, trying to clear his mind. There had to be something he was missing, some connection he hadn't made yet.

And then it hit him. The pattern. Or rather, the lack of one. The systems had gone down simultaneously, but what if that was the point? What if someone—or something—had intentionally caused the failure?

"DeSalle, run a full diagnostic on the computer core. Look for any signs of tampering or anomalies," Scotty ordered, a new urgency in his voice.

Minutes felt like hours as they waited for the results. When DeSalle's face appeared on the screen, it was pale. "Scotty, there’s a foreign signal embedded in the core. It’s masked, but it’s there."

Scotty’s heart raced. "Can you isolate it?"

"I’m trying. It’s complex, like nothing I’ve seen before."

Scotty joined him at the console, his eyes narrowing as he examined the code. It was sophisticated, designed to blend in with the ship’s normal operations. Whoever had done this knew the Enterprise inside and out.

"Scotty, we’ve got it," DeSalle said finally. "It’s a subroutine, designed to shut down all primary systems."

"Can you disable it?"

"I think so, but it’ll take time."

"Do it. And be quick about it."

As DeSalle worked, Scotty felt a glimmer of hope. They were on the right track. The minutes ticked by agonizingly slowly, but finally, DeSalle looked up. "It’s done."

Scotty activated the main power switch, holding his breath. There was a hum, then a surge of light as the systems came back online. He let out a breath he didn’t realize he’d been holding.

"Captain, we’ve restored power," he reported.

"Good work, Scotty. What happened?"

"An embedded signal in the computer core, sir. Sabotage, most likely."

"We’ll deal with the who and why later. For now, get us moving."

"Aye, sir."

As the Enterprise resumed its journey, Scotty allowed himself a moment of relief. They had survived, thanks to ingenuity and determination. But as he looked around at his crew, he knew the real challenge was yet to come. Who had sabotaged them, and why? That was a mystery for another day.

writing_prompt: When a relentless agent arrives to audit Peter's team, Neal finds himself under suspicion for a forgery he didn’t commit. To clear his name—and protect Peter—he hatches a plan that might just blur the line between clever and reckless.
story:
Neal Caffrey sat in the conference room, his usual charm replaced with an unusual tension. Across the table, Agent Calloway, the relentless auditor, leafed through the files with a hawk-like intensity. Neal could feel the weight of her gaze even when she wasn’t looking directly at him. The room was thick with unspoken accusations, and the air seemed to hum with an impending storm.

Peter Burke stood by the window, his arms crossed, his jaw set in a determined line. He hadn’t said much since Calloway arrived, but Neal could see the strain in his eyes. This wasn’t just an audit; it was a hunt, and Neal was the prey. The accusation of forgery had come out of nowhere, and it was clear Calloway had her sights set on Neal, believing the reformed conman had slipped back into his old ways.

“Mr. Caffrey,” Calloway said, her voice slicing through the silence, “explain to me how your signature ended up on this document.” She slid a piece of paper across the table. Neal didn’t need to look at it to know it was a forgery. He hadn’t signed anything remotely resembling it, but it was a near-perfect imitation of his signature, the kind he would have admired if the situation were different.

Neal leaned forward, his eyes meeting hers with a mix of defiance and sincerity. “I didn’t sign that, Agent Calloway. I don’t know who did, but it wasn’t me.”

Calloway’s lips curled into a skeptical smile. “Right. And I suppose you have an alibi?”

Neal glanced at Peter, who gave him a slight nod. “Actually, I do. I was with Peter the entire day in question. We were working a case.”

Peter stepped forward, his voice calm but firm. “That’s correct. Neal was with me the whole time. There’s no way he could have forged that document.”

Calloway raised an eyebrow. “Convenient, but not proof. I’ll need more than your word, Agent Burke.”

Neal knew he had to act fast. The longer this dragged on, the more it would tarnish Peter’s reputation and the trust they had built. He needed to find the real forger, and he needed to do it without crossing the line. Or at least, not crossing it too far.

That night, Neal sat in his apartment, his mind racing. The forgery was good—too good. It had to be someone who knew his style, someone with access. He thought about the cases they’d worked on, the people they’d encountered. One name kept coming back to him: Keller. He had the skill and the motive to set Neal up.

Neal knew what he had to do, but it was risky. He needed to get Keller to confess, and the only way to do that was to confront him directly. He couldn’t involve Peter—this was his mess to clean up.

The following evening, Neal found himself in a dimly lit bar on the edge of the city. Keller was there, as he expected, nursing a drink and looking as smug as ever. Neal slid into the seat across from him, his heart pounding but his face calm.

“Keller,” Neal said, his voice low and steady, “I know you forged that document. I need you to clear my name.”

Keller chuckled, leaning back in his chair. “Neal, Neal, Neal. Always the innocent one. Why would I do that?”

“Because if you don’t,” Neal said, leaning in, “I’ll make sure every criminal in the city knows you’ve been working with the FBI. You’ll be a walking target.”

Keller’s eyes narrowed, the smile fading from his lips. “You wouldn’t.”

“Try me,” Neal said, his voice cold. “I’m not asking for much. Just clear my name, and we both walk away.”

Keller studied him for a moment, then sighed. “Fine. But you owe me, Caffrey.”

Neal nodded, knowing he was making a dangerous promise. “Deal.”

The next day, an anonymous tip led Calloway to Keller’s hideout, where she found enough evidence to prove he was the forger. The charges against Neal were dropped, and the audit ended with Peter’s team cleared of any wrongdoing.

As they walked out of the office, Peter clapped a hand on Neal’s shoulder. “You did good, Neal. Reckless, but good.”

Neal smiled, the tension finally easing from his shoulders. “Thanks, Peter. I couldn’t have done it without you.”

Peter shook his head, a hint of a smile playing at his lips. “Just try to stay out of trouble for once, will you?”

Neal laughed. “No promises.”
